awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2: Extreme floods on the lower Mississippi River in the context of late Holocene climatic variability
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mississippi River plays a fundamental role in the economy of the United States, and flooding along its course is costly in both economic and social terms. Historic flooding of the lower Mississippi in 2011 caused over $3 billion in agricultural losses and damage to infrastructure, with additional losses to flooding occurring again in 2016 and 2018. Seasonal and longer-term predictions of flooding along the Mississippi and its major tributaries remain a major challenge because the effects of climate variability, greenhouse forcing, and human modifications of the river are difficult to disentangle using short records from gauging stations that span less than 150 years. This project will develop records describing the timing and magnitude of flooding across the Mississippi River basin over the last millennium, and use these records to understand the influence of climate variability on flood activity. This work will improve predictions of flooding along the Mississippi River, a hazard that affects millions of people. The findings will be useful for planned and ongoing efforts to slow coastal land loss in the Mississippi River delta. The project will engage students at three institutions in research, and its findings will be disseminated to the public through an exhibit at the Mississippi River Museum and Aquarium. 


The goal of this project is to reconstruct the frequency and magnitude of overbank floods along the lower Mississippi River and its major tributaries over the last millennium using the sedimentary archives preserved in oxbow lakes. Our ability to create this novel hydrological record is due to recent developments in paleoflood hydrology that demonstrate the unique ability of floodplain lake sediments to record individual flood events and their associated magnitude. Once developed, our reconstructions will be used to characterize decadal- to centennial-scale variability of flood activity, to compare with simulated discharge extremes in climate model ensembles, and to identify the regional and hemispheric circulation patterns associated with increased likelihoods of extreme floods on the lower Mississippi River and its major tributaries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
River flooding is among the most costly and deadly natural hazards and has a complex relationship with climate change, the type of land cover in the river basin, and anthropogenic management of the river system. It is expected that flooding will get worse due to future climate change. The Lower Mississippi River (LMR) plays a fundamental role in the economy of the United States, and extreme floods are costly in both economic and social terms. The instrumental record of LMR flooding covers only about 150 years, and longer flooding records are needed to identify the role of the different contributing flood-control factors. In this project, we extended the records of overbank flooding of the LMR and its major distributaries using various sedimentary archives.

For the LMR, sedimentary records preserved in multiple lakes surrounding the river were investigated. The coarseness of the lake sediments is strongly correlated with the discharge of the LMR and is thus used to identify LMR flooding and calculate their magnitudes. The ages of the lake sediments were measured using a combination of multiple dating techniques. The compiled flooding record spans the past 500 years. It shows that past flooding changes of the LMR correlated with the temperature variations in both the tropical Pacific and the Northern Atlantic oceans at a multi-decadal timescale, demonstrating the climatic control of LMR flooding. The magnitude of LMR flooding has been amplified during the past century primarily due to river embankments, highlighting the profound impact of human activity on flooding for a large river system.

We also investigated sedimentary records of extreme flooding of the Ohio River, the largest distributary of the LMR in terms of discharge. Slackwater deposits, the type of materials deposited by an elevated river on ledges, rock shelters, and caves, are used in this case. The advantage of using slackwater deposits is that the stage of a flooding river, so flood discharge, can be measured by the height of the deposits. We used geochemical and sedimentological analysis to identify slackwater deposits and measured the age of those deposits using optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating. We identified two slackwater deposits corresponding to the AD 1937 historic flood of record (~31,400 m3/s) and a paleoflood with a discharge of ~23,900 m3/s that occurred around AD 1650, respectively. Our findings imply that the AD 1937 flood represents the largest magnitude flood on the lower Ohio River in at least the last 400 years.

Overall, our research demonstrates that the sedimentary archives are extremely useful for extending flooding records of rivers beyond instrumental records. The extended records are important to understand the natural and anthropogenic factors controlling river flooding. We showed that flood control measures such as embankments, although providing short-term flood-risk mitigation, can amplify flood hazards in the long term. Thus, other risk mitigation strategies are crucial for long-term success. This project provided training opportunities in geology for two CCU undergraduate students.
